History of Present Illness (HPI): The patient experiences frustration with her daughter not cleaning her room, which occasionally leads to anger, but she generally does not feel heatedly angry, and little things from her children can be annoying
Medical and Psychiatric History: The patient has a history of anxiety and depression, diagnosed approximately five to six years ago. She has experienced anxiety since her teenage years, and while it has been off and on throughout her life, it is currently under control
Psychosocial History: The patient is a homemaker, married for 22 years, and has five children. She enjoys traveling, particularly to Israel, where she recently renewed her marriage vows. She has a close relationship with her best friends, who are sisters she grew up with. Her faith and church community are significant influences in her life. She is currently considering moving in with her elderly parents to provide support as they age
Physiological Observations: The patient reports difficulty sleeping, often waking up at least once during the night, primarily to use the bathroom. She sometimes struggles to fall back asleep if she wakes up too early
Current Functional Status: The patient manages a busy household, home-schooling her son, and engages in family activities. She finds relaxation in playing word games and watching TV with her husband after dinner. She feels a sense of accomplishment when completing chores and errands
Therapeutic Interventions: The patient has been involved in therapy for her daughter, who suffers from anxiety. They have participated in a six-month group therapy focused on Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT), which has been beneficial for both her daughter and the family
